column2: ENGLISH
You leave the setting to court the rising sun. -Tiberius Claudius Nero Caesar
Boni pastoris est tondere pecus, non deglubere. (A good shepherd shears his sheep, he doesn't flay them.) -Tiberius Claudius Nero Caesar
Right action is better than knowledge, but in order to do what is right, we must know what is right. -Charlemagne
I do not steal victory. -Megas Alexandros, before the Battle of Gaugamela, in response to Parmenion's suggestion that he attack the Persian camp at night
There is nothing impossible to him who will try. -Megas Alexandros
Are you still to learn that the end and perfection of our victories is to avoid the vices and infirmities of those whom we subdue? -Megas Alexandros
For my part, I assure you, I had rather excel others in the knowledge of what is excellent, than in the extent of my power and dominion. -Megas Alexandros
Kratistos! (To the strongest!) -Megas Alexandros, purported last words regarding who will inherit his empire
Don't fear sometime ceasing to live, but do fear never beginning to live in accord with nature. -Marcus Aurelius
A reflective, contented mind is the best possession. -Zarathustra, Ushtavaiti Gatha, Yasna 43, 15.
Satisfaction linked with dishonor or with harm to others is a prison for the seeker. -Zarathustra, Vahishto-Ishti Gatha, Yasna 53, 6.
Truly, it is easy to do evil. -Ashoka the Great
All men are my children. What I desire for my own children, and I desire their welfare and happiness both in this world and the next, that I desire for all men. -Ashoka the Great

Let my skin and sinews and bones dry up, together with all the flesh and blood of my body! I welcome it! But I will not move from this spot until I have attained the supreme and final wisdom. -Gautama Buddha
That army of yours, that the world with its devas can't overcome, I will smash with discernment. -Gautama Buddha
All compounded things are subject to decay. Strive with diligence! -Gautama Buddha, last words
Utinam populus Romanus unam cervicem haberet! (Would that the Roman people had but one neck!) -Caligula
To do no evil is good, to intend none better. -Claudius Caesar Augustus Germanicus
No one is free who does not lord over himself. -Claudius Caesar Augustus Germanicus
Whom the gods love dies young. -Menandros of Athens
The man who runs may fight again. -Menander of Athens
There is no instance of a nation benefitting from prolonged warfare. -Sun Zi
As material fortune is associated with the properties of the body, so honor belongs to those of the soul. -Claudius Ptolemaeus
Everything that is hard to attain is easily assailed by the generality of men. -Claudius Ptolemaeus
Numberless are the world's wonders, but none more wonderful than man. -Sophokles
Fortune is not on the side of the faint-hearted. -Sophokles
Vae, puto deus fio! (Oh dear! I think I'm becoming a god!) -Vespasian, on his deathbed, in mockery of Alexandros II
It is convenient that there be gods, and, as it is convenient, let us believe that there are. -Publius Ovidius Naso
Tempus edax rerum. (Time, the devourer of all things.) -Publius Ovidius Naso
Finge datos currus, quid agas? (Suppose the chariot of the sun were given you, what would you do?) -Publius Ovidius Naso
Kindness is a mark of faith, and whoever has not kindness has not faith. -Muhammad
Know that Paradise is under the shades of swords. -Muhammad

Avoid cruelty and injustice for, on the Day of Judgment, the same will turn into several darknesses, and guard yourselves against miserliness, for this has ruined nations who lived before you. -Muhammad
It is better for a leader to make a mistake in forgiving than to make a mistake in punishing. -Muhammad
For those who practice tyranny and deprive others of their rights, I will be harsh and stern, but for those who follow the law, I will be most soft and tender. -'Umar ibn Al-Khattab
The wisest man is he who can account for his actions. -'Umar ibn Al-Khattab
The weakest man is the one who is able to correct his moral defects, but doesn't take action. -Ali bin Abu-Talib
A friend cannot be considered a friend unless he is tested on three occasions: in time of need, behind your back, and after your death. -Ali bin Abu-Talib
There are two sides to every question. -Protagoras
Man is the measure of all things: of things which are, that they are, and of things which are not, that they are not. -Protagoras
Listen — I say that justice is nothing other than the advantage of the stronger. -Plato
The people have always some champion whom they set over them and nurse into greatness... This and no other is the root from which a tyrant springs: when he first appears he is a protector. -Plato
No human thing is of serious importance. -Plato
And happiness is thought to depend on leisure, for we are busy that we may have leisure, and make war that we may live in peace. -Aristotle
Man is by nature a political animal. -Aristotle
Give me the place to stand, and I shall move the earth. -Archimedes
To ravage, to slaughter, to usurp under false titles, they call empire, and where they make a desert, they call it peace. -Publius Tacitus
Deos fortioribus adesse. (The gods are on the side of the stronger.) -Publius Tacitus
Because they didn't know better, they called it 'civilization,' when it was part of their slavery. -Publius Tacitus
Once killing starts, it is difficult to draw the line. -Publius Tacitus
Very little is needed to make a happy life. -Marcus Aurelius
Do not think that what is hard for you to master is humanly impossible, but if a thing is humanly possible, consider it to be within your reach. -Marcus Aurelius
All men are made one for another: either then teach them better, or bear with them. -Marcus Aurelius
Waste no more time arguing what a good man should be. Be one. -Marcus Aurelius
Veni, vidi, vici. (I came, I saw, I conquered.) -Gaius Iulius Caesar
Alea iacta est. (The die is cast.) -Gaius Iulius Caesar
Fortune, which has a great deal of power in other matters but especially in war, can bring about great changes in a situation through very slight forces. -Gaius Iulius Caesar
Fere libenter homines id quod volunt credunt. (Men willingly believe what they wish.) -Gaius Iulius Caesar
It is not the well-fed, long-haired man I fear, but the pale and the hungry looking. -Gaius Iulius Caesar
I am not bothered by the fact that I am not understood. I am bothered when I do not know others. -Kong Fu Zi
To study and not think is a waste. To think and not study is dangerous. -Kong Fu Zi
The cautious seldom err. -Kong Fu Zi
Nihil infinitum est. (Nothing is infinite.) -Seneca the Elder
Omnia mors poscit. Lex est, non poena, perire. (All things death claims. 'Tis law, not punishment, to die.) -Seneca the Elder
Magni pectoris est inter secunda moderatio. (It is the sign of a great spirit to be moderate in prosperity.) -Seneca the Elder
Iniquum est conlapsis manum non porrigere. Commune hoc ius generis humani est. (It is wrong not to give a hand to the fallen. This right is common to the whole human race.) -Seneca the Elder

Non quia difficilia sunt non audemus, sed quia non audemus difficilia sunt. (Our lack of confidence is not the result of difficulty. The difficulty comes from our lack of confidence.) -Seneca the Younger
Ignis aurum probat, miseria fortes uiros. (Fire tries gold, misfortune tries brave men.) -Seneca the Younger
Confragosa in fastigium dignitatis via est. (It is a rough road that leads to the heights of greatness.) -Seneca the Younger
Ignoranti quem portum petat nullus suus ventus est. (If one does not know to which port one is sailing, no wind is favourable.) -Seneca the Younger

The study of history is the best medicine for a sick mind, for in history you have a record of the infinite variety of human experience plainly set out for all to see: and in that record you can find for yourself and your country both examples and warnings. -Titus Livius
Men are slower to recognise blessings than misfortunes. -Titus Livius
Fortune blinds men when she does not wish them to withstand the violence of her onslaughts. -Titus Livius
Vae victis! (Woe to the vanquished!) -Titus Livius
There is nothing that is more often clothed in an attractive garb than a false creed. -Titus Livius
